abstract_summ: Primary outcome of this meta-analysis was case fatality rate defined by total number of deaths divided by total number of diagnosed cases.Estimates of case fatality ratio from international cases stratified by age were consistent with those from China (parametric estimate 1·4% [0·4–3·5] in those aged <60 years [n=360] and 4·5% [1·8–11·1] in those aged ≥60 years [n=151]).We also estimated the case fatality ratio from individual line-list data on 1334 cases identified outside of mainland China.Methods: We collected the number of laboratory-confirmed cases and deaths in South Korea from the World Health Organization (as of 21 March, 2020) and case distribution and fatality rates by age from the Korean Center for Disease Control and Prevention (as of 22 March, 2020).Conclusions Our estimates of CFR based on laboratory-confirmed cases ascertained outside of Hubei suggest that COVID-19 is not as severe as severe acute respiratory syndrome and Middle East respiratory syndrome, but more similar to the mortality risk of 2009 H1N1 influenza pandemic in hospitalized patients.
title_summ: COVID-19 Fatality and Comorbidity Risk Factors among Confirmed Patients in MexicoRelative Coronavirus Disease 2019 Mortality: A Swiss Population-based StudyCase- fatality rate in COVID- 19 patients: A meta-analysis of publicly accessible databasePopulation-Level Mortality Rates from Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) in South KoreaEstimates of the severity of coronavirus disease 2019: a model-based analysisCase fatality risk of novel coronavirus diseases 2019 in ChinaThe Burden of Disease due to COVID-19 in Korea Using Disability-Adjusted Life YearsCase fatality risk of the first pandemic wave of novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in ChinaAscertainment rate of novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in JapanReporting of notifiable infectious diseases during the COVID-19 response.Analysis of COVID-19 under-reporting in Brazil.
title_abstract_phrases: Primary outcome of this meta-analysis was case fatality rate defined by total number of deaths divided by total number of diagnosed cases.Estimates of case fatality ratio from international cases stratified by age were consistent with those from China (parametric estimate 1·4% [0·4–3·5] in those aged <60 years [n=360] and 4·5% [1·8–11·1] in those aged ≥60 years [n=151]).We also estimated the case fatality ratio from individual line-list data on 1334 cases identified outside of mainland China.Conclusions Our estimates of CFR based on laboratory-confirmed cases ascertained outside of Hubei suggest that COVID-19 is not as severe as severe acute respiratory syndrome and Middle East respiratory syndrome, but more similar to the mortality risk of 2009 H1N1 influenza pandemic in hospitalized patients.COVID-19 Fatality and Comorbidity Risk Factors among Confirmed Patients in MexicoAs of April 18, 2020, 2.16 million patients in the world had been tested positive with Coronavirus (COVID-19) and 146,088 had died, which accounts for a case fatality rate of 6.76%.
